content.raw:
I like the notation, but is there still a way in which we can represent what is being mobilized?

e.g. `X_JJm(q)` or something?
content.html:
I like the notation, but is there still a way in which we can represent what is being mobilized?

e.g. X_JJm(q) or something?

content.raw: thanks; that's my understanding as well

In Gazebo, I believe the joint frame is attached to the child body. So `J` is **not** the same as `J0`. This aligns with the SDF spec in that the joint pose is specified relative to the child link frame.

If `X_CJ` is the *fixed* transform from child to joint (which is what is specified by the `<pose>` tag of a joint), `X_MJ = X_MC * X_CJ`. So in Drake notation, `J` is `M`. I do like the idea of having different attached-to-parent and attached-to-child frames, but the SDF spec currently provides only the latter.
content.html:
In Gazebo, I believe the joint frame is attached to the child body. So J is not the same as J0. This aligns with the SDF spec in that the joint pose is specified relative to the child link frame.

If X_CJ is the fixed transform from child to joint (which is what is specified by the <pose> tag of a joint), X_MJ = X_MC * X_CJ. So in Drake notation, J is M. I do like the idea of having different attached-to-parent and attached-to-child frames, but the SDF spec currently provides only the latter.
fixed with 7d1d9bbbf72e in pull request #4

content.raw:
Thanks for working on this guys! A lil note from me. The choice `F` and `M` where not arbitrary. 1\) Our monogram notation does work best when frames's names are single characters names. 2\) If you think of a tree structure \(you dont have to! but many times we do\), we chose `F` for the "fixed" frame attached to the inboard body and similarly we chose `M` for the “mobilized” frame \(as a way of saying “the frame across the joint that moves with respect to F”\). So this convention help us internally when reading code that has to do with the actual tree structure. Again, users should not think in terms of trees when writing an SDF, but if it so happens that your SDF describes something simple like a chain, it’s not that bad making that analogy.   
That’s it, my 2 cents. I hope you find it useful. Thanks again!
content.html:
Thanks for working on this guys! A lil note from me. The choice F and M where not arbitrary. 1) Our monogram notation does work best when frames's names are single characters names. 2) If you think of a tree structure (you dont have to! but many times we do), we chose F for the "fixed" frame attached to the inboard body and similarly we chose M for the “mobilized” frame (as a way of saying “the frame across the joint that moves with respect to F”). So this convention help us internally when reading code that has to do with the actual tree structure. Again, users should not think in terms of trees when writing an SDF, but if it so happens that your SDF describes something simple like a chain, it’s not that bad making that analogy.
That’s it, my 2 cents. I hope you find it useful. Thanks again!

content.raw:
In \[drake@361223416\]\([https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/tree/361223416](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/tree/361223416)\), for the`MultibodyPlant` design, @{557058:82e5965f-3de7-463a-8d2f-5eb310e3ca12} defined the joint has frames `F` and `M`, s.t. the forward kinematics are computed as `X_FM(q_joint)`:

* `F` is the joint frame attached to the parent body `P`
* `M` is the joint frame attached to the child body `B`

[https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen\_cxx/classdrake\_1\_1multibody\_1\_1\_multibody\_plant.html#ac828f1c818a0ed3f47ff5f342fa0ee0c](https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen_cxx/classdrake_1_1multibody_1_1_multibody_plant.html#ac828f1c818a0ed3f47ff5f342fa0ee0c)

[https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen\_cxx/classdrake\_1\_1multibody\_1\_1internal\_1\_1\_mobilizer.html#a2e004244a2c950d12c321610559eeac0](https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen_cxx/classdrake_1_1multibody_1_1internal_1_1_mobilizer.html#a2e004244a2c950d12c321610559eeac0)

While we don't have to use these frame names \(as we already use `M` for the model frame in this context\), it is _really_ nice to have explicit and _different_ frames for the “across the joint” transform.

`X_J0J` is an option, but doesn't look that great, and kinda has the the implementation baked into it. I'd be happy with something like `X_KJ` or whatever, as long as we’re concise.

EDIT: Grahhh! I really dislike BitBucket’s text editor :disappointed:
content.html:
In [drake@361223416](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/tree/361223416), for theMultibodyPlant design, @Alejandro Castro defined the joint has frames F and M, s.t. the forward kinematics are computed as X_FM(q_joint):

  • F is the joint frame attached to the parent body P
  • M is the joint frame attached to the child body B

https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen_cxx/classdrake_1_1multibody_1_1_multibody_plant.html#ac828f1c818a0ed3f47ff5f342fa0ee0c

https://drake.mit.edu/doxygen_cxx/classdrake_1_1multibody_1_1internal_1_1_mobilizer.html#a2e004244a2c950d12c321610559eeac0

While we don't have to use these frame names (as we already use M for the model frame in this context), it is really nice to have explicit and different frames for the “across the joint” transform.

X_J0J is an option, but doesn't look that great, and kinda has the the implementation baked into it. I'd be happy with something like X_KJ or whatever, as long as we’re concise.

EDIT: Grahhh! I really dislike BitBucket’s text editor

content.raw:
To clarify, what is the joint frame `J` exactly?

Let’s say the _fixed_ transform between the parent and joint is `J0`.

Is `J` the same as `J0`?

Or does it happen “after movement”, i.e. `X_MJ = X_MP * X_PJ0 * X_J0J(q_joint)` \(where `q_joint` are the DOFs for the joint\)?

\(I’ll take a peek at Drake to see what we denote as the joint frame.\)
content.html:
To clarify, what is the joint frame J exactly?

Let’s say the fixed transform between the parent and joint is J0.

Is J the same as J0?

Or does it happen “after movement”, i.e. X_MJ = X_MP * X_PJ0 * X_J0J(q_joint) (where q_joint are the DOFs for the joint)?

(I’ll take a peek at Drake to see what we denote as the joint frame.)

content.raw: \(Feel free to ignore this\) 0.78 radians is rather imprecise; can we make the approximation more explicit, just by adding `of 0.78 radians (~45 degrees)`?
content.html: (Feel free to ignore this) 0.78 radians is rather imprecise; can we make the approximation more explicit, just by adding of 0.78 radians (~45 degrees)?

content.raw:
> If we have a vector, p_{P} in the parent link frame and wanted to express it in the model frame, we'd simply multiply the pose of the parent link with the vector right?

I was assuming that the link `<pose>` tag represents the transform from the model frame `M` to the link "Parent" frame `P`. To go from parent link from to model frame, I think you'd need to use the inverse of the link pose?
content.html:
If we have a vector, p_{P} in the parent link frame and wanted to express it in the model frame, we'd simply multiply the pose of the parent link with the vector right?

I was assuming that the link <pose> tag represents the transform from the model frame M to the link "Parent" frame P. To go from parent link from to model frame, I think you'd need to use the inverse of the link pose?

content.raw:
I think we're in agreement about the convention, but I'm still not sure if `{xyz_PM}` is the correct notation. If we have a vector, `p_{P}` in the parent link frame and wanted to express it in the model frame, we'd simply multiply the pose of the parent link with the vector right? So if the pose of the parent link is `X_{PM}` this product would be:

`p_{M} = X_{PM} * p_{P}`

Doesn't the convention suggest

`p_{M} = X_{MP} * p_{P}`

with `X_{MP}` instead of `X_{PM}`?
content.html:
I think we're in agreement about the convention, but I'm still not sure if {xyz_PM} is the correct notation. If we have a vector, p_{P} in the parent link frame and wanted to express it in the model frame, we'd simply multiply the pose of the parent link with the vector right? So if the pose of the parent link is X_{PM} this product would be:

p_{M} = X_{PM} * p_{P}

Doesn't the convention suggest

p_{M} = X_{MP} * p_{P}

with X_{MP} instead of X_{PM}?

content.raw:
I think this is the convention

`p_{to} = X_{to}{from} * p_{from}`

so to parent link `P` from model `M` would be `{xyz_PM}`?
content.html:
I think this is the convention

p_{to} = X_{to}{from} * p_{from}

so to parent link P from model M would be {xyz_PM}?

content.raw: Are the suffixes reversed per [this comment](#!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/5/pose-frame-semantics-describe-legacy/activity#comment-95427103)? For example, I think we want `xyz` of the parent link w.r.t the model, which I believe would be `{xyz_MP}`.
content.html: Are the suffixes reversed per this comment? For example, I think we want xyz of the parent link w.r.t the model, which I believe would be {xyz_MP}.

content.raw: I would put the use_parent_model frame stuff in an intermediate or advanced tutorial since it was never really a part of the spec, just a workaround for a bug in gazebo
content.html: I would put the use_parent_model frame stuff in an intermediate or advanced tutorial since it was never really a part of the spec, just a workaround for a bug in gazebo

content.raw: Thanks for catching this. The joint axis has never been specified relative to the child link frame. Should we mention that it used to be specified in the parent model frame in v1.4?
content.html: Thanks for catching this. The joint axis has never been specified relative to the child link frame. Should we mention that it used to be specified in the parent model frame in v1.4?
